      <tr>
        <td id="L38" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="38"></td>
        <td id="LC38" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">STAT 547 can roughly be divided into two main ideas or themes: <span class="pl-mb">**reproducible workflows**</span> and <span class="pl-mb">**interactive dashboards**</span>.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L39" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="39"></td>
        <td id="LC39" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In the first part of the course we will start working with writing functions in R scripts and think a little bit about functional programming.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L40" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="40"></td>
        <td id="LC40" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Then with some new tools at our disposal, we will create &quot;analysis pipelines&quot; to automate and streamline the process going from loading raw data, all the way to creating a final report with the results of a regression analysis.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L41" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="41"></td>
        <td id="LC41" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Next we&#39;ll switch gears and use our functional programming skills to create a dashboard app with multiple interactive components and multi-page/tab layouts.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L42" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="42"></td>
        <td id="LC42" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Finally we will end with deploying our dashboard to a free cloud service so that it is publicly available!</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L43" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="43"></td>
        <td id="LC43" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">It is my hope that you will use the things we learn in this course to inform your own data analysis pipelines in your PhD and Masters research projects.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L44" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="44"></td>
        <td id="LC44" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">To that end, if you ever have questions about these tools could be used in your projects, feel free to drop by my office hours and I&#39;d be happy to discuss it!</td>
      </tr>

      <tr>
        <td id="L165" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="165"></td>
        <td id="LC165" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">We will import this data first by installing (if necessary, using <span class="pl-c1">`install.packages(&quot;tidyverse&quot;)`</span>) the tidyverse collection of packages and then calling the <span class="pl-c1">`read_csv`</span> function.</td>

        <td id="LC167" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r library-install, eval = TRUE, message = TRUE, warning = TRUE}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>

</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L171" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="171"></td>
        <td id="LC171" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Loading the tidyverse gives us eight packages (ggplot2, tibble, <span class="pl-c1">`tidyr`</span>, <span class="pl-c1">`readr`</span>, <span class="pl-c1">`purr`</span>, <span class="pl-c1">`dplyr`</span>, <span class="pl-c1">`stringr`</span>, <span class="pl-c1">`forcats`</span>.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L172" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="172"></td>
        <td id="LC172" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">One of those, <span class="pl-c1">`dplyr`</span>, defines two functions that mask standard functions in R with the same names.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L173" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="173"></td>
        <td id="LC173" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">If we need the originals, we can always get them with their fully-qualified names referring to the original package they belong to: <span class="pl-c1">`stats::filter`</span> and <span class="pl-c1">`stats::lag`</span>.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L174" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="174"></td>
        <td id="LC174" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Firas&#39; note: I find these errors and messages quite irritating so I have made it so they do not appear unless I explicitly ask it to (which I did in this case for illustrative purposes).</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L175" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="175"></td>
        <td id="LC175" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L176" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="176"></td>
        <td id="LC176" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">At any time, we can call <span class="pl-c1">`sessionInfo()`</span> to find out what versions of which packages we have loaded, along with the version of R we&#39;re using and some other useful information:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L177" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="177"></td>
        <td id="LC177" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>

        <td id="LC178" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L179" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="179"></td>
        <td id="LC179" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">sessionInfo()</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L180" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="180"></td>
        <td id="LC180" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L181" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="181"></td>
        <td id="LC181" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Once we have the tidyverse loaded, reading the file looks remarkably like reading the file:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L182" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="182"></td>
        <td id="LC182" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L275" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="275"></td>

</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L276" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="276"></td>
        <td id="LC276" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">But notice that the output is not a vector, but another tibble (i.e., a table with N rows and one column).</td>

      <tr>

</td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L283" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="283"></td>
        <td id="LC283" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">How then are we to get the first mention of Afghanistan?</td>

      <tr>

</td>
      </tr>

        <td id="LC286" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r double-square-on-tibble, output.lines=NA}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L289" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="289"></td>

</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L290" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="290"></td>
        <td id="LC290" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">This is now a plain old vector, so it can be indexed with single square brackets:</td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L291" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="291"></td>
        <td id="LC291" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L292" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="292"></td>
        <td id="LC292" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r double-square-then-single}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L293" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="293"></td>
        <td id="LC293" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">infant_hiv</span>[[<span class="pl-c1">1</span>]][<span class="pl-c1">1</span>]</span></td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L294" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="294"></td>

</td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L296" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="296"></td>
        <td id="LC296" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">But that too is a vector, so it can of course be indexed as well (for some value of &quot;of course&quot;):</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L297" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="297"></td>
        <td id="LC297" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L298" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="298"></td>
        <td id="LC298" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r double-single-single}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L299" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="299"></td>
        <td id="LC299" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">infant_hiv</span>[[<span class="pl-c1">1</span>]][<span class="pl-c1">1</span>][<span class="pl-c1">1</span>]</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L300" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="300"></td>
        <td id="LC300" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L301" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="301"></td>
        <td id="LC301" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L302" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="302"></td>
        <td id="LC302" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Thus, <span class="pl-c1">`data[1][[1]]`</span> produces a tibble, then selects the first column vector from it, so it still gives us a vector. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L303" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="303"></td>
        <td id="LC303" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mi">*This is not madness.*</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L304" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="304"></td>
        <td id="LC304" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">It is merely...differently sane.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L305" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="305"></td>
        <td id="LC305" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L306" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="306"></td>
        <td id="LC306" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c1">&gt;</span> <span class="pl-mb">**Subsetting Data Frames**</span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L307" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="307"></td>
        <td id="LC307" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c1">&gt;</span></span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L308" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="308"></td>
        <td id="LC308" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c1">&gt;</span> When we are working with data frames (including tibbles),</span></span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L309" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="309"></td>
        <td id="LC309" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c1">&gt;</span> subsetting with a single vector selects columns, not rows,</span></span></span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L310" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="310"></td>
        <td id="LC310" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c1">&gt;</span> because data frames are stored as lists of columns.</span></span></span></span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L311" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="311"></td>
        <td id="LC311" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c1">&gt;</span> This means that <span class="pl-c1">`df[1:2]`</span> selects two columns from <span class="pl-c1">`df`</span>.</span></span></span></span></span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L312" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="312"></td>
        <td id="LC312" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c1">&gt;</span> However, in <span class="pl-c1">`df[2:3, 1:2]`</span>, the first index selects rows, while the second selects columns.</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L313" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="313"></td>
        <td id="LC313" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c"></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L314" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="314"></td>
        <td id="LC314" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>How do I calculate basic statistics?</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L315" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="315"></td>
        <td id="LC315" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L316" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="316"></td>
        <td id="LC316" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">What is the average estimate?</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L317" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="317"></td>
        <td id="LC317" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">We start by grabbing that column for convenience:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L318" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="318"></td>
        <td id="LC318" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L319" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="319"></td>
        <td id="LC319" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r r-average-index}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L320" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="320"></td>
        <td id="LC320" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">estimates</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">infant_hiv</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">estimate</span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L321" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="321"></td>
        <td id="LC321" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">length(<span class="pl-smi">estimates</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L322" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="322"></td>
        <td id="LC322" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L323" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="323"></td>
        <td id="LC323" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r r-estimates-mean}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L324" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="324"></td>
        <td id="LC324" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">mean(<span class="pl-smi">estimates</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L325" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="325"></td>
        <td id="LC325" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L326" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="326"></td>
        <td id="LC326" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L327" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="327"></td>
        <td id="LC327" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The void is always there, waiting for us...</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L328" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="328"></td>
        <td id="LC328" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Let&#39;s fix this in R first by telling <span class="pl-c1">`mean`</span> to drop NAs:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L329" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="329"></td>
        <td id="LC329" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L330" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="330"></td>
        <td id="LC330" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r r-remove-na}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L331" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="331"></td>
        <td id="LC331" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">mean(<span class="pl-smi">estimates</span>, <span class="pl-v">na.rm</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">TRUE</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L332" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="332"></td>
        <td id="LC332" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L333" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="333"></td>
        <td id="LC333" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L334" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="334"></td>
        <td id="LC334" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Many functions in R use <span class="pl-c1">`na.rm`</span> to control whether <span class="pl-c1">`NA`</span>s are removed or not.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L335" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="335"></td>
        <td id="LC335" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(Remember, the <span class="pl-c1">`.`</span> character is just another part of the name)</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L336" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="336"></td>
        <td id="LC336" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">R&#39;s default behavior is to leave <span class="pl-c1">`NA`</span>s in, and then to include them in aggregate computations.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L337" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="337"></td>
        <td id="LC337" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L338" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="338"></td>
        <td id="LC338" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">A good use of aggregation is to check the quality of the data.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L339" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="339"></td>
        <td id="LC339" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">For example, we can ask if there are any records where some of the estimate, the low value, or the high value are missing,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L340" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="340"></td>
        <td id="LC340" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r r-check-null}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L341" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="341"></td>
        <td id="LC341" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">any(is.na(<span class="pl-smi">infant_hiv</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">hi</span>) <span class="pl-k">!=</span> is.na(<span class="pl-smi">infant_hiv</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">lo</span>))</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L342" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="342"></td>
        <td id="LC342" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L343" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="343"></td>
        <td id="LC343" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L344" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="344"></td>
        <td id="LC344" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mb">**Aside:**</span> In R, there&#39;s a handy package called <span class="pl-c1">`glue`</span>.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L345" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="345"></td>
        <td id="LC345" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The <span class="pl-c1">`glue`</span> package is very useful for &quot;gluing&quot; strings to data in R.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L346" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="346"></td>
        <td id="LC346" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Let&#39;s load it to see how it works:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L347" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="347"></td>
        <td id="LC347" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L348" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="348"></td>
        <td id="LC348" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r r-min-max-std}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L349" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="349"></td>
        <td id="LC349" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">library(<span class="pl-smi">glue</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L350" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="350"></td>
        <td id="LC350" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L351" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="351"></td>
        <td id="LC351" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">print(glue(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span>min {min(estimates, na.rm = TRUE)}<span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span></span>))</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L352" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="352"></td>
        <td id="LC352" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">print(glue(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span>max {max(estimates, na.rm = TRUE)}<span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span></span>))</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L353" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="353"></td>
        <td id="LC353" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">print(glue(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span>sd {sd(estimates, na.rm = TRUE)}<span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span></span>))</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L354" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="354"></td>
        <td id="LC354" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L355" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="355"></td>
        <td id="LC355" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L356" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="356"></td>
        <td id="LC356" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>How do I filter data?</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L357" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="357"></td>
        <td id="LC357" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L358" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="358"></td>
        <td id="LC358" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">By &quot;filtering&quot;, we mean &quot;selecting records by value&quot;.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L359" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="359"></td>
        <td id="LC359" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The simplest approach is to use a vector of logical values to keep only the values corresponding to <span class="pl-c1">`TRUE`</span>:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L360" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="360"></td>
        <td id="LC360" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r r-simple-filter}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L361" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="361"></td>
        <td id="LC361" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">maximal</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">estimates</span>[<span class="pl-smi">estimates</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span><span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.95</span>]</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L362" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="362"></td>
        <td id="LC362" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">length(<span class="pl-smi">maximal</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L363" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="363"></td>
        <td id="LC363" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L364" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="364"></td>
        <td id="LC364" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r r-maximal, output.lines=NA}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L365" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="365"></td>
        <td id="LC365" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">maximal</span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L366" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="366"></td>
        <td id="LC366" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L367" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="367"></td>
        <td id="LC367" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L368" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="368"></td>
        <td id="LC368" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">It appears that R has kept the unknown values in order to highlight just how little we know.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L369" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="369"></td>
        <td id="LC369" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">More precisely, wherever there was an <span class="pl-c1">`NA`</span> in the original data, there is an <span class="pl-c1">`NA`</span> in the logical vector and hence, an <span class="pl-c1">`NA`</span> in the final vector.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L370" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="370"></td>
        <td id="LC370" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Let us then turn to <span class="pl-c1">`which`</span> to get a vector of indices at which a vector contains <span class="pl-c1">`TRUE`</span>.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L371" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="371"></td>
        <td id="LC371" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">This function does not return indices for <span class="pl-c1">`FALSE`</span> or <span class="pl-c1">`NA`</span>:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L372" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="372"></td>
        <td id="LC372" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L373" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="373"></td>
        <td id="LC373" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r r-which}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L374" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="374"></td>
        <td id="LC374" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">which(<span class="pl-smi">estimates</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span><span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.95</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L375" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="375"></td>
        <td id="LC375" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L376" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="376"></td>
        <td id="LC376" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L377" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="377"></td>
        <td id="LC377" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">And as a quick check:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L378" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="378"></td>
        <td id="LC378" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L379" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="379"></td>
        <td id="LC379" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r r-length-which}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L380" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="380"></td>
        <td id="LC380" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">length(which(<span class="pl-smi">estimates</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span><span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.95</span>))</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L381" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="381"></td>
        <td id="LC381" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L382" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="382"></td>
        <td id="LC382" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L383" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="383"></td>
        <td id="LC383" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">So now we can index our vector with the result of the <span class="pl-c1">`which`</span>:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L384" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="384"></td>
        <td id="LC384" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L385" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="385"></td>
        <td id="LC385" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r r-maximal-which}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L386" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="386"></td>
        <td id="LC386" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">maximal</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">estimates</span>[which(<span class="pl-smi">estimates</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span><span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.95</span>)]</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L387" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="387"></td>
        <td id="LC387" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">maximal</span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L388" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="388"></td>
        <td id="LC388" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L389" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="389"></td>
        <td id="LC389" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L390" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="390"></td>
        <td id="LC390" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">But should we do this?</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L391" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="391"></td>
        <td id="LC391" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Those <span class="pl-c1">`NA`</span>s are important information, and should not be discarded so blithely.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L392" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="392"></td>
        <td id="LC392" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">What we should <span class="pl-mi">*really*</span> be doing is using the tools the tidyverse provides rather than clever indexing tricks.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L393" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="393"></td>
        <td id="LC393" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">These behave consistently across a wide scale of problems and encourage use of patterns that make it easier for others to understand our programs.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L394" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="394"></td>
        <td id="LC394" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L395" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="395"></td>
        <td id="LC395" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>How do I write tidy code?</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L396" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="396"></td>
        <td id="LC396" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L397" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="397"></td>
        <td id="LC397" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The six basic data transformation operations in the tidyverse are:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L398" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="398"></td>
        <td id="LC398" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L399" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="399"></td>
        <td id="LC399" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span> <span class="pl-c1">`filter`</span>: choose observations (rows) by value(s)</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L400" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="400"></td>
        <td id="LC400" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span> <span class="pl-c1">`arrange`</span>: reorder rows</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L401" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="401"></td>
        <td id="LC401" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span> <span class="pl-c1">`select`</span>: choose variables (columns) by name</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L402" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="402"></td>
        <td id="LC402" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span> <span class="pl-c1">`mutate`</span>: derive new variables from existing ones</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L403" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="403"></td>
        <td id="LC403" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span> <span class="pl-c1">`group_by`</span>: define subsets of rows for further processing</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L404" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="404"></td>
        <td id="LC404" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span> <span class="pl-c1">`summarize`</span>: combine many values to create a single new value</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L405" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="405"></td>
        <td id="LC405" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L406" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="406"></td>
        <td id="LC406" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">`filter(tibble, ...criteria...)`</span> keeps rows that pass all of the specified criteria:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L407" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="407"></td>
        <td id="LC407" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L408" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="408"></td>
        <td id="LC408" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r filter-as-function}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L409" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="409"></td>
        <td id="LC409" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">filter(<span class="pl-smi">infant_hiv</span>, <span class="pl-smi">lo</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.5</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L410" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="410"></td>
        <td id="LC410" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L411" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="411"></td>
        <td id="LC411" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L412" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="412"></td>
        <td id="LC412" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Notice that the expression is <span class="pl-c1">`lo &gt; 0.5`</span> rather than <span class="pl-c1">`&quot;lo&quot; &gt; 0.5`</span>.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L413" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="413"></td>
        <td id="LC413" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The latter expression would return the entire table because the string <span class="pl-c1">`&quot;lo&quot;`</span> is greater than the number 0.5 everywhere.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L414" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="414"></td>
        <td id="LC414" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L415" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="415"></td>
        <td id="LC415" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">But how is it that the name <span class="pl-c1">`lo`</span> can be used on its own?</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L416" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="416"></td>
        <td id="LC416" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">It is the name of a column, but there is no variable called <span class="pl-c1">`lo`</span>.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L417" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="417"></td>
        <td id="LC417" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The answer is that R uses lazy evaluation: function arguments aren&#39;t evaluated until they&#39;re needed, so the function <span class="pl-c1">`filter`</span> actually gets the expression <span class="pl-c1">`lo &gt; 0.5`</span>, which allows it to check that there&#39;s a column called <span class="pl-c1">`lo`</span> and then use it appropriately.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L418" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="418"></td>
        <td id="LC418" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">It may seem strange at first, but it is much tidier than <span class="pl-c1">`filter(data, data$lo &gt; 0.5)`</span> or <span class="pl-c1">`filter(data, &quot;lo &gt; 0.5&quot;)`</span>.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L419" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="419"></td>
        <td id="LC419" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L420" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="420"></td>
        <td id="LC420" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">We can make data anlaysis code more readable by using the pipe operator <span class="pl-c1">`%&gt;%`</span>:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L421" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="421"></td>
        <td id="LC421" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L422" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="422"></td>
        <td id="LC422" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r filter-in-pipe}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L423" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="423"></td>
        <td id="LC423" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">infant_hiv</span> %<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>% filter(<span class="pl-smi">lo</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.5</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L424" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="424"></td>
        <td id="LC424" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L425" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="425"></td>
        <td id="LC425" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L426" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="426"></td>
        <td id="LC426" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">This may not seem like much of an improvement,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L427" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="427"></td>
        <td id="LC427" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">but neither does a Unix pipe consisting of <span class="pl-c1">`cat filename.txt | head`</span>.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L428" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="428"></td>
        <td id="LC428" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">What about this?</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L429" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="429"></td>
        <td id="LC429" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L430" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="430"></td>
        <td id="LC430" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r filter-complex}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L431" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="431"></td>
        <td id="LC431" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">filter(<span class="pl-smi">infant_hiv</span>, (<span class="pl-smi">estimate</span> <span class="pl-k">!=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.95</span>) <span class="pl-k">&amp;</span> (<span class="pl-smi">lo</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.5</span>) <span class="pl-k">&amp;</span> (<span class="pl-smi">hi</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span><span class="pl-k">=</span> (<span class="pl-smi">lo</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.1</span>)))</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L432" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="432"></td>
        <td id="LC432" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L433" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="433"></td>

      <tr>

        <td id="LC505" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">  filter(<span class="pl-smi">hi</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span><span class="pl-k">=</span> (<span class="pl-smi">lo</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.2</span>)) %<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>%</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L506" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="506"></td>
        <td id="LC506" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">  mutate(<span class="pl-v">difference</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">hi</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">lo</span>) %<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>%</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L507" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="507"></td>
        <td id="LC507" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">  group_by(<span class="pl-smi">year</span>) %<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>%</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L508" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="508"></td>
        <td id="LC508" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">  summarize(<span class="pl-v">count</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> n(), <span class="pl-v">ave_diff</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> mean(<span class="pl-smi">year</span>))</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L509" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="509"></td>
        <td id="LC509" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L510" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="510"></td>
        <td id="LC510" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L511" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="511"></td>
        <td id="LC511" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Elegant, right?</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L512" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="512"></td>
        <td id="LC512" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L513" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="513"></td>
        <td id="LC513" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>How do I model my data?</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L514" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="514"></td>
        <td id="LC514" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L515" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="515"></td>
        <td id="LC515" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Tidying up data can be as calming and rewarding in the same way as knitting or rearranging the specimen jars on the shelves in your dining room-stroke-laboratory.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L516" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="516"></td>
        <td id="LC516" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Eventually, though, people want to do some statistics.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L517" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="517"></td>
        <td id="LC517" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The simplest tool for this in R is <span class="pl-c1">`lm`</span>, which stands for &quot;linear model&quot;.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L518" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="518"></td>
        <td id="LC518" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Given a formula and a data set, it calculates coefficients to fit that formula to that data:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L519" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="519"></td>
        <td id="LC519" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L520" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="520"></td>
        <td id="LC520" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r simple-formula}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L521" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="521"></td>
        <td id="LC521" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">model</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> lm(<span class="pl-smi">estimate</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> <span class="pl-smi">lo</span>, <span class="pl-v">data</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">infant_hiv</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L522" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="522"></td>
        <td id="LC522" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">model</span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L523" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="523"></td>
        <td id="LC523" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L524" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="524"></td>
        <td id="LC524" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L525" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="525"></td>
        <td id="LC525" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">This is telling us that <span class="pl-c1">`estimate`</span> is more-or-less equal to <span class="pl-c1">`0.0421 + 1.0707 * lo`</span>.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L526" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="526"></td>
        <td id="LC526" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The <span class="pl-c1">`~`</span> symbol is used to separate the left and right sides of the equation, and as with all things tidyverse, lazy evaluation allows us to use variable names directly.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L527" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="527"></td>
        <td id="LC527" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L528" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="528"></td>
        <td id="LC528" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Recall another handy R package <span class="pl-c1">`broom`</span> that helps us work with the output of <span class="pl-c1">`lm`</span> in the tidyverse way:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L529" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="529"></td>
        <td id="LC529" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L530" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="530"></td>
        <td id="LC530" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L531" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="531"></td>
        <td id="LC531" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">library(<span class="pl-smi">broom</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L532" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="532"></td>
        <td id="LC532" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">tidy(<span class="pl-smi">model</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L533" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="533"></td>
        <td id="LC533" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L534" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="534"></td>
        <td id="LC534" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L535" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="535"></td>
        <td id="LC535" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">You&#39;ll note that the same information is now presented to usin a more familiar form (a tibble).</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L536" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="536"></td>
        <td id="LC536" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The row names have been moved into a column called term, and the column names are consistent and can be accessed using $.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L537" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="537"></td>
        <td id="LC537" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L538" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="538"></td>
        <td id="LC538" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In case you are interested in the fitted values and residuals for each of the original points in the regression. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L539" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="539"></td>
        <td id="LC539" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">For this, use <span class="pl-c1">`augment`</span>:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L540" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="540"></td>
        <td id="LC540" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L541" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="541"></td>
        <td id="LC541" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L542" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="542"></td>
        <td id="LC542" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">augment(<span class="pl-smi">model</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L543" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="543"></td>
        <td id="LC543" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L544" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="544"></td>
        <td id="LC544" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L545" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="545"></td>
        <td id="LC545" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Note that each of the new columns begins with a &#39;.&#39; to avoid overwriting any of the original columns.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L546" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="546"></td>
        <td id="LC546" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Finally, several summary statistics are computed for the entire regression, such as R^2 and the F-statistic. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L547" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="547"></td>
        <td id="LC547" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">These can be accessed with the <span class="pl-c1">`glance`</span> function:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L548" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="548"></td>
        <td id="LC548" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L549" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="549"></td>
        <td id="LC549" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L550" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="550"></td>
        <td id="LC550" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">glance(<span class="pl-smi">model</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L551" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="551"></td>
        <td id="LC551" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L552" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="552"></td>
        <td id="LC552" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L553" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="553"></td>
        <td id="LC553" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L554" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="554"></td>
        <td id="LC554" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In fact, it lets us write much more complex formulas involving functions of multiple variables.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L555" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="555"></td>
        <td id="LC555" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">For example, we can regress <span class="pl-c1">`estimate`</span> against the square roots of <span class="pl-c1">`lo`</span> and <span class="pl-c1">`hi`</span> (though there is no sound statistical reason to do so):</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L556" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="556"></td>
        <td id="LC556" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L557" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="557"></td>
        <td id="LC557" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r complex-formula}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L558" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="558"></td>
        <td id="LC558" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">model2</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> lm(<span class="pl-smi">estimate</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> sqrt(<span class="pl-smi">lo</span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span> sqrt(<span class="pl-smi">hi</span>), <span class="pl-v">data</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">infant_hiv</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L559" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="559"></td>
        <td id="LC559" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">model2</span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L560" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="560"></td>
        <td id="LC560" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L561" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="561"></td>
        <td id="LC561" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L562" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="562"></td>
        <td id="LC562" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Let&#39;s take amoment to describe how the <span class="pl-c1">`+`</span> is overloaded in formulas.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L563" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="563"></td>
        <td id="LC563" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The formula <span class="pl-c1">`estimate ~ lo + hi`</span> does <span class="pl-mi">*not*</span> mean &quot;regress <span class="pl-c1">`estimate`</span> against the sum of <span class="pl-c1">`lo`</span> and <span class="pl-c1">`hi`</span>&quot;,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L564" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="564"></td>
        <td id="LC564" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">but rather, &quot;regress <span class="pl-c1">`estimate`</span> against the two variables <span class="pl-c1">`lo`</span> and <span class="pl-c1">`hi`</span>&quot;:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L565" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="565"></td>
        <td id="LC565" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L566" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="566"></td>
        <td id="LC566" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r double-regression}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L567" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="567"></td>
        <td id="LC567" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">model3</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> lm(<span class="pl-smi">estimate</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> <span class="pl-smi">lo</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> <span class="pl-smi">hi</span>, <span class="pl-v">data</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">infant_hiv</span>)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L568" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="568"></td>
        <td id="LC568" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">model3</span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L569" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="569"></td>
        <td id="LC569" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L570" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="570"></td>
        <td id="LC570" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L571" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="571"></td>
        <td id="LC571" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">If we want to regress <span class="pl-c1">`estimate`</span> against the average of <span class="pl-c1">`lo`</span> and <span class="pl-c1">`hi`</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L572" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="572"></td>
        <td id="LC572" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(i.e., regress <span class="pl-c1">`estimate`</span> against a single calculated variable instead of against two variables)</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L573" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="573"></td>
        <td id="LC573" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">we need to create a temporary column:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L574" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="574"></td>
        <td id="LC574" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L575" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="575"></td>
        <td id="LC575" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r regress-temporary}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L576" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="576"></td>
        <td id="LC576" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">infant_hiv</span> %<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>%</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L577" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="577"></td>
        <td id="LC577" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">  mutate(<span class="pl-v">ave_lo_hi</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> (<span class="pl-smi">lo</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> <span class="pl-smi">hi</span>)<span class="pl-k">/</span><span class="pl-c1">2</span>) %<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>%</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L578" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="578"></td>
        <td id="LC578" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">  lm(<span class="pl-smi">estimate</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> <span class="pl-smi">ave_lo_hi</span>, <span class="pl-v">data</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> .)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L579" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="579"></td>
        <td id="LC579" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L580" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="580"></td>
        <td id="LC580" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L581" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="581"></td>
        <td id="LC581" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Here, the call to <span class="pl-c1">`lm`</span> is using the variable <span class="pl-c1">`.`</span> to mean &quot;the data coming in from the previous stage of the pipeline&quot;.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L582" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="582"></td>
        <td id="LC582" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Most of the functions in the tidyverse use this convention so that data can be passed to a function that expects it in a position other than the first.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L583" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="583"></td>
        <td id="LC583" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L584" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="584"></td>
        <td id="LC584" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>How do I create a plot?</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L585" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="585"></td>
        <td id="LC585" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L586" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="586"></td>
        <td id="LC586" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Human being always want to see the previously unseen, though they are not always glad to have done so.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L587" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="587"></td>
        <td id="LC587" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The most popular tool for doing this in R is <span class="pl-c1">`ggplot2`</span>, which implements and extends the patterns for creating charts described in <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">Wilk2005</span>.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L588" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="588"></td>
        <td id="LC588" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Every chart it creates has a geometry that controls how data is displayed and a mapping that controls how values are represented geometrically.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L589" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="589"></td>
        <td id="LC589" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">For example, these lines of code create a scatter plot showing the relationship between <span class="pl-c1">`lo`</span> and <span class="pl-c1">`hi`</span> values in the infant HIV data:</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L590" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="590"></td>
        <td id="LC590" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L591" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="591"></td>
        <td id="LC591" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r basic-plot}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L592" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="592"></td>
        <td id="LC592" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">ggplot(<span class="pl-smi">infant_hiv</span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span> </span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L593" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="593"></td>
        <td id="LC593" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">  geom_point(<span class="pl-v">mapping</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> aes(<span class="pl-v">x</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">lo</span>, <span class="pl-v">y</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">hi</span>)) <span class="pl-k">+</span></span></td>
      </tr>

</td>

        <td id="LC598" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Looking more closely:</td>

</td>

        <td id="LC600" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span>   The function <span class="pl-c1">`ggplot`</span> creates an object to represent the chart with <span class="pl-c1">`infant_hiv`</span> as the underlying data.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L601" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="601"></td>

        <td id="LC603" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">    that specifies <span class="pl-c1">`lo`</span> is to be used as the <span class="pl-c1">`x`</span> coordinate and <span class="pl-c1">`hi`</span> is to be used as the <span class="pl-c1">`y`</span> coordinate.</td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L604" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="604"></td>
        <td id="LC604" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span>   The <span class="pl-c1">`theme_bw()`</span> is added to the plot to remove the default grey background</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L605" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="605"></td>
        <td id="LC605" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span>   The elements of the chart are combined with <span class="pl-c1">`+`</span> rather than <span class="pl-c1">`%&gt;%`</span> for historical reasons.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L606" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="606"></td>
        <td id="LC606" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L607" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="607"></td>
        <td id="LC607" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Let&#39;s create a slightly more appealing plot by dropping NAs, making the points semi-transparent, and colorizing them according to the value of <span class="pl-c1">`estimate`</span>:</td>

      <tr>

      <tr>
        <td id="L621" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="621"></td>
        <td id="LC621" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">We set the transparency <span class="pl-c1">`alpha`</span> outside the aesthetic because its value is constant for all points.</td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L622" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="622"></td>
        <td id="LC622" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">If we set it inside <span class="pl-c1">`aes(...)`</span>, we would be telling ggplot2 to set the transparency according to the value of the data.</td>

        <td id="L623" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="623"></td>
        <td id="LC623" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">We specify the limits to the axes manually with <span class="pl-c1">`xlim`</span> and <span class="pl-c1">`ylim`</span> to ensure that ggplot2 includes the upper bounds.</td>

        <td id="LC624" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Without this, all of the data would be shown, but the upper label &quot;1.00&quot; would be omitted.</td>

      <tr>
